title: How to Do a Split Stitch

steps.headline: Thread your needle with an even number of threads.
steps.description: Get out embroidery floss in the color you want to use and pull off as many threads as you want to sew with. In order to make your split stitches balanced, choose an even number of threads. Then, tie the end of the threads together in a knot. You could sew with 4 threads, for instance, or 6 threads, if you want thicker stitches.

steps.headline: Trace an outline or design on your fabric.
steps.description: Lay a piece of embroidery fabric on a flat work surface and use a chalk-based marking pencil or standard pencil to lightly draw your design or outline.Variation: If you'll be embroidering a detailed image, consider using an iron-on transfer so you don't have to sketch or trace on the fabric. If you're only practicing the stitch and not following a pattern, try sewing straight lines of split stitch until you get the hang of it. Then, you can practice split stitching curves.

steps.headline: Mount the fabric in an embroidery hoop.
steps.description: Loosen the screw on the hoop to separate the embroidery hoops. Place the inner hoop under the fabric so your traced design is in the center. Push the outer hoop that has the screw down on top of the fabric and tighten the screw so the fabric is taut. If the fabric isn't tight enough in the hoop, it will be harder to make your split stitches.

steps.headline: Sew a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) straight stitch.
steps.description: Bring the tip of the needle from under the fabric up through the start of the line or pattern you drew. Keep pulling the needle to bring the thread through. Then, push the needle down through the fabric about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) away from the start of the stitch. Pull the thread through to make 1 stitch. If you'd like to sew a curve, you might want to make your stitches even smaller so you get a high level of detail.

steps.headline: Bring the needle up through the middle of the first stitch.
steps.description: Your needle should be underneath the fabric at this point. To split the stitch you just made, bring just the tip of the needle through the middle of the previous stitch. Wiggle the needle tip a little so you split the threads evenly. This will make your stitch look balanced. For example, if you're working with 4 threads of embroidery floss, there should be 2 threads on each side of the needle.

steps.headline: Pull the thread and insert it about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) away from the stitch.
steps.description: Draw the needle up so the thread is taut. Then, push the needle down through the fabric about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) away from the end of the first stitch you made. This will give you the next straight stitch to split stitch into.

steps.headline: Continue to sew into the middle of each stitch across your pattern.
steps.description: Try to keep the distance between the stitches consistent. This will make your chain of split stitches appear even. Sew until you reach the end of your line or pattern. If the stitch looks twisted, use your thumb and index finger to roll the thread under the fabric until the stitch lays flat.

steps.headline: Tie off the thread on the back of the hoop.
steps.description: Once you've finished sewing your line or pattern, bring the needle down so it's underneath the fabric. Tie a knot in the thread where it meets the underside of the fabric and then cut the thread.Did You Know? If you look at the underside of the fabric, the split stitches will look like standard backstitches. The knot will secure your stitches.

steps.headline: Make a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) straight stitch.
steps.description: Push the needle tip up through the fabric so it comes out at the start of the pattern or line you traced. Bring the needle up and pull the thread taut. Then, insert the needle about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) from the start of the stitch and pull the thread through the fabric. This will make 1 straight stitch. To make split stitches along a curve, sew smaller stitches. The needle should now be underneath the fabric on your hoop.

steps.headline: Push the needle up about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) from the end of the first stitch.
steps.description: Keep in mind that you'll be sewing slightly in front of the stitch you just made. Pull the needle until the thread is taut.Did You Know? The split backstitch uses as much as 20 to 25% more thread than the standard split stitch.

steps.headline: Insert your needle into the middle of the previous stitch.
steps.description: Ensure that there are an equal number of threads on both sides of the needle. Then push the needle down and pull the thread through to make a split backstitch. Ensure there are any even number of threads on each side of the needle before you push the needle through the fabric.

steps.headline: Sew split backstitches across the line or design you traced.
steps.description: Continue to stitch back into the stitch you just made as you work across your design. If you've made these stitches correctly, they should look just like standard split stitches on the front of your fabric. If you turn the embroidery hoop over, you'll see that the split backstitches form a connected line. This is why this stitch uses more embroidery floss than the standard split stitch.

steps.headline: Tie a knot at the back of the hoop and cut the thread.
steps.description: Turn the hoop over once you've finished sewing. Tie a tight knot near the underside of the fabric. Then, you can cut the thread and remove the fabric from the hoop.
